awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Understanding and Control over Electrokinetic Assembly and Separation of Colloids in pH Gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
Separating micron-sized particles in liquids is an important operation in many chemical processes. The separation of particles based on differences in composition or surface properties is especially challenging because it cannot be achieved with conventional filter-based methods. Nevertheless, these separations are important in many environmental and industrial applications, including particle removal from wastewater, assessing levels of microplastics in waterways, and cell assays using whole blood. Electric fields represent a promising solution for separating colloids because they allow spatial control over particles in large- and small-scale devices and are energy efficient. This research project investigates the concurrent use of electric fields and pH gradients to manipulate micron scale colloidal particles and to control their assembly and separation. Interactions between the colloid surface chemistry, the pH gradient, and the electric field lead to a dynamic surface charge on the colloids as they move through the pH gradient.  This dynamic property results in a wide range of new phenomena such as particle levitation, separation of colloids based on size, density, and surface chemistry, and formation of bilayer colloidal films. The project researchers will conduct experiments to determine how particle composition, size, shape, and surface chemistry affect the behavior of colloidal particles in electric fields and pH gradients. The research team will host high school students for 9-month research internships.  The group also will develop and administer laboratory modules demonstrating colloid and interfacial science phenomena to middle school students at a summer STEM camp at the University of Maryland. Aspects from the research project will be integrated into a graduate-level course on colloid and interfacial science.

This research project aims to measure the phoretic and advective motion of micron-scale colloids in pH gradients and low frequency (< 1 kHz) oscillatory electric fields and to establish the underlying electrokinetic forces. Microscopic pH gradients will be generated electrochemically near the electrode surface by redox reactions of electroactive quinone molecules, which consume or generate protons at the electrode-electrolyte interface. The behavior of the colloids in a parallel plate electrochemical cell will be observed with optical and confocal microscopy. The colloids will experience various competitive and synergistic phoretic and advective forces, including electrophoresis, electroosmosis, electrohydrodynamic fluid flow, and sedimentation, which together will determine the assembly state and levitation height of colloids above the electrode surface. A scaling model for the electrokinetic forces acting on the colloids will reveal that dynamic colloid surface charge and dipole field interact synergistically to control particle assembly state and to levitate colloids to a unique position above the electrode that depends on the particle and electric field properties. These phenomena will be exploited to demonstrate that mixtures of similarly sized particles with different shapes and different surface chemistries can be separated and assembled into bilayer colloidal crystals.

por.por_cntn:
Active colloids driven by electric fields have potential applications as micromotors and microrobots for drug delivery, fabrication of thin protective films, wastewater cleanup, responsive optical materials, and particle separation technologies. Conventional approaches have utilized single mode electric fields to drive assembly and propulsion of colloids. The use of multimodal electric fields and electrochemical reactions to simultaneously drive electrokinetic flows and modify solution conditions has the potential to add additional degrees of control over the motion of colloids in electric fields. This project aimed to investigate the single particle and collective behavior of colloids in multimode electric fields, i.e., electric fields with both a steady and oscillating component, using a combination of video optical microscopy, quantitative image analysis, and theoretical modeling. Interestingly, our group found that electrochemical redox of a common electroactive molecule used in redox flow batteries, benzoquinone, could reproducibly generate pH gradients and pH transients in colloid filled electrochemical reactors. pH gradients and transients were directly observed by fluorescence microscopy and were modeled using numerical electrochemical transport simulations. These simulations revealed that pH transients were generated due to opposing acidic and alkaline waves from each electrode. The colloids responded to the electric field and electrochemical pH control by displaying novel active behavior, such as aggregation, separation, swarming, levitation, and transient assembly. The steady state aggregation and separation of the colloids under electrochemical control provided an important experimental verification of recent theoretical work on rectified electric fields in electrolyte solutions.

Our group’s findings on active colloids in electric fields and the presence of electrochemical reactions have expanded fundamental understanding of colloidal electrokinetics and their use to control the assembly and propulsion of colloids. The most important finding was that electrochemical reactions can be used in conjunction with oscillatory electric fields to modify electrokinetic flows around colloids. This work demonstrates that electrochemical reactions provide an additional control knob for mediating the direction and magnitude of electrokinetic flows around colloids. In addition to the experimental observations, we have developed rigorous numerical and scaling models that establish concrete connections between the electrochemical reaction intermediates, electric fields, hydrodynamics, and colloidal particle dynamics. This work emphasizes the importance of multiscale modeling and mechanistic understanding to bridge the gap between electrochemical and colloidal phenomena. The novel colloidal phenomena discovered in this study are expected to contribute to development of advanced multiphase materials with broad societal benefits, such as responsive optical materials, new fabrication methods for thin protective coatings, electrochemical sensors, and micromotor and microrobots for wastewater clean up and drug delivery.
